name: ResearchStudy
description: A process where a researcher or organization plans and then executes a series of steps intended to increase the field of healthcare-related knowledge.  This includes studies of safety, efficacy, comparative effectiveness and other information about medications, devices, therapies and other interventional and investigative techniques.  A ResearchStudy involves the gathering of information about human or animal subjects.

properties.name: ResearchStudy
properties.short: Investigation to increase healthcare-related patient-independent knowledge
properties.definition: A process where a researcher or organization plans and then executes a series of steps intended to increase the field of healthcare-related knowledge.  This includes studies of safety, efficacy, comparative effectiveness and other information about medications, devices, therapies and other interventional and investigative techniques.  A ResearchStudy involves the gathering of information about human or animal subjects.
properties.comment: Need to make sure we encompass public health studies.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
properties.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

properties.name: meta
properties.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

properties.name: implicitRules
properties.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
properties.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
properties.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

properties.name: language
properties.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
properties.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

properties.name: text
properties.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
properties.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
properties.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

properties.name: contained
properties.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
properties.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

properties.name: extension
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: modifierExtension
properties.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: identifier
properties.definition: Identifiers assigned to this research study by the sponsor or other systems.

properties.name: name
properties.definition: Name for this study (computer friendly).

properties.name: title
properties.short: Human readable name of the study
properties.definition: The human readable name of the research study.

properties.name: label
properties.definition: Additional names for the study.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: extension
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. properties.name: type
properties.short: primary | official | scientific | plain-language | subtitle | short-title | acronym | earlier-title | language | auto-translated | human-use | machine-use | duplicate-uid
properties.definition: Kind of name.

properties.name: value
properties.definition: The name.

properties.name: protocol
properties.definition: The set of steps expected to be performed as part of the execution of the study.

properties.name: partOf
properties.definition: A larger research study of which this particular study is a component or step.

properties.name: status
properties.short: active | administratively-completed | approved | closed-to-accrual | closed-to-accrual-and-intervention | completed | disapproved | in-review | temporarily-closed-to-accrual | temporarily-closed-to-accrual-and-intervention | withdrawn
properties.definition: The current state of the study.

properties.name: primaryPurposeType
properties.short: treatment | prevention | diagnostic | supportive-care | screening | health-services-research | basic-science | device-feasibility
properties.definition: The type of study based upon the intent of the study's activities. A classification of the intent of the study.

properties.name: phase
properties.short: n-a | early-phase-1 | phase-1 | phase-1-phase-2 | phase-2 | phase-2-phase-3 | phase-3 | phase-4
properties.definition: The stage in the progression of a therapy from initial experimental use in humans in clinical trials to post-market evaluation.

properties.name: studyDesign
properties.short: Classifications of the study design characteristics
properties.definition: Codes categorizing the type of study such as investigational vs. observational, type of blinding, type of randomization, safety vs. efficacy, etc.

properties.name: category
properties.definition: Codes categorizing the type of study such as investigational vs. observational, type of blinding, type of randomization, safety vs. efficacy, etc.

properties.name: focus
properties.definition: The medication(s), food(s), therapy(ies), device(s) or other concerns or interventions that the study is seeking to gain more information about.

properties.name: condition
properties.definition: The condition that is the focus of the study.  For example, In a study to examine risk factors for Lupus, might have as an inclusion criterion "healthy volunteer", but the target condition code would be a Lupus SNOMED code.

properties.name: contact
properties.definition: Contact details to assist a user in learning more about or engaging with the study.

properties.name: relatedArtifact
properties.definition: Citations, references, URLs and other related documents.  When using relatedArtifact to share URLs, the relatedArtifact.type will often be set to one of "documentation" or "supported-with" and the URL value will often be in relatedArtifact.document.url but another possible location is relatedArtifact.resource when it is a canonical URL.

properties.name: keyword
properties.short: Used to search for the study
properties.definition: Key terms to aid in searching for or filtering the study.

properties.name: location
properties.definition: Indicates a country, state or other region where the study is taking place.

properties.name: region
properties.definition: A country, state or other area where the study is taking place rather than its precise geographic location or address.

properties.name: descriptionSummary
properties.definition: A brief text for explaining the study.

properties.name: description
properties.definition: A detailed and human-readable narrative of the study. E.g., study abstract.

properties.name: enrollment
properties.definition: Reference to a Group that defines the criteria for and quantity of subjects participating in the study.  E.g. " 200 female Europeans between the ages of 20 and 45 with early onset diabetes".
properties.comment: The Group referenced should not generally enumerate specific subjects.  Subjects will be linked to the study using the ResearchSubject resource.

properties.name: period
properties.short: When the study began and ended
properties.definition: Identifies the start date and the expected (or actual, depending on status) end date for the study.

properties.name: sponsor
properties.short: Organization that initiates and is legally responsible for the study
properties.definition: An organization that initiates the investigation and is legally responsible for the study.

properties.name: principalInvestigator
properties.short: Researcher who oversees multiple aspects of the study
properties.definition: A researcher in a study who oversees multiple aspects of the study, such as concept development, protocol writing, protocol submission for IRB approval, participant recruitment, informed consent, data collection, analysis, interpretation and presentation.

properties.name: site
properties.short: Facility where study activities are conducted
properties.definition: A facility in which study activities are conducted.

properties.name: reasonStopped
properties.definition: A description and/or code explaining the premature termination of the study.

properties.name: note
properties.definition: Comments made about the study by the performer, subject or other participants.

properties.name: arm
properties.short: Defined path through the study for a subject
properties.definition: Describes an expected sequence of events for one of the participants of a study.  E.g. Exposure to drug A, wash-out, exposure to drug B, wash-out, follow-up.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: name
properties.definition: Unique, human-readable label for this arm of the study.

properties.name: type
properties.definition: Categorization of study arm, e.g. experimental, active comparator, placebo comparater.

properties.name: description
properties.definition: A succinct description of the path through the study that would be followed by a subject adhering to this arm.

properties.name: classifier
properties.definition: Additional grouping mechanism or categorization of a research study. Example: FDA regulated device, FDA regulated drug, MPG Paragraph 23b (a German legal requirement), IRB-exempt, etc. Implementation Note: do not use the classifier element to support existing semantics that are already supported thru explicit elements in the resource.

properties.name: associatedParty
properties.definition: Sponsors, collaborators, and other parties.
properties.comment: For a Sponsor or a PrincipalInvestigator use the dedicated attributes provided.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: name
properties.definition: Name of associated party.

properties.name: role
properties.short: sponsor | lead-sponsor | sponsor-investigator | primary-investigator | collaborator | funding-source | general-contact | recruitment-contact | sub-investigator | study-director | study-chair
properties.definition: Type of association.

properties.name: period
properties.definition: Identifies the start date and the end date of the associated party in the role.
properties.comment: The cardinality is 0..* due to the fact that an associated party may be intermittently active in a given role over multiple time periods.

properties.name: classifier
properties.short: nih | fda | government | nonprofit | academic | industry
properties.definition: A categorization other than role for the associated party.

properties.name: party
properties.short: Individual or organization associated with study (use practitionerRole to specify their organisation)
properties.definition: Individual or organization associated with study (use practitionerRole to specify their organisation).
properties.comment: Suggestions of a better attribute name are appreciated

properties.name: progressStatus
properties.short: Status of study with time for that status
properties.definition: Status of study with time for that status.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: state
properties.short: Label for status or state (e.g. recruitment status)
properties.definition: Label for status or state (e.g. recruitment status).

properties.name: actual
properties.definition: An indication of whether or not the date is a known date when the state changed or will change. A value of true indicates a known date. A value of false indicates an estimated date.

properties.name: period
properties.definition: Date range.

properties.name: whyStopped
properties.definition: A description and/or code explaining the premature termination of the study.

properties.name: recruitment
properties.short: Target or actual group of participants enrolled in study
properties.definition: Target or actual group of participants enrolled in study.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: targetNumber
properties.short: Estimated total number of participants to be enrolled
properties.definition: Estimated total number of participants to be enrolled.

properties.name: actualNumber
properties.short: Actual total number of participants enrolled in study
properties.definition: Actual total number of participants enrolled in study.

properties.name: eligibility
properties.definition: Inclusion and exclusion criteria.

properties.name: actualGroup
properties.short: Group of participants who were enrolled in study
properties.definition: Group of participants who were enrolled in study.

properties.name: comparisonGroup
properties.short: Defined path through the study for a subject
properties.definition: Describes an expected event or sequence of events for one of the subjects of a study. E.g. for a living subject: exposure to drug A, wash-out, exposure to drug B, wash-out, follow-up. E.g. for a stability study: {store sample from lot A at 25 degrees for 1 month}, {store sample from lot A at 40 degrees for 1 month}.
properties.comment: In many clinical trials this is refered to as the ARM of the study, but such a term is not used in other sorts of trials even when there is a comparison between two or more groups.

properties.name: linkId
properties.short: Allows the comparisonGroup for the study and the comparisonGroup for the subject to be linked easily
properties.definition: Allows the comparisonGroup for the study and the comparisonGroup for the subject to be linked easily.

properties.name: name
properties.definition: Unique, human-readable label for this comparisonGroup of the study.

properties.name: type
properties.definition: Categorization of study comparisonGroup, e.g. experimental, active comparator, placebo comparater.

properties.name: description
properties.definition: A succinct description of the path through the study that would be followed by a subject adhering to this comparisonGroup.

properties.name: intendedExposure
properties.short: Interventions or exposures in this comparisonGroup or cohort
properties.definition: Interventions or exposures in this comparisonGroup or cohort.

properties.name: observedGroup
properties.short: Group of participants who were enrolled in study comparisonGroup
properties.definition: Group of participants who were enrolled in study comparisonGroup.

properties.name: objective
properties.definition: A goal that the study is aiming to achieve in terms of a scientific question to be answered by the analysis of data collected during the study.

properties.name: name
properties.definition: Unique, human-readable label for this objective of the study.

properties.name: type
properties.definition: The kind of study objective.

properties.name: description
properties.definition: Free text description of the objective of the study.  This is what the study is trying to achieve rather than how it is going to achieve it (see ResearchStudy.description).

properties.name: outcomeMeasure
properties.short: A variable measured during the study
properties.definition: An "outcome measure", "endpoint", "effect measure" or "measure of effect" is a specific measurement or observation used to quantify the effect of experimental variables on the participants in a study, or for observational studies, to describe patterns of diseases or traits or associations with exposures, risk factors or treatment.
properties.comment: A study may have multiple distinct outcome measures that can be used to assess the overall goal for a study. The goal of a study is in the objective whereas the metric by which the goal is assessed is the outcomeMeasure. Examples: Time to Local Recurrence (TLR), Disease-free Survival (DFS), 30 Day Mortality, Systolic BP

properties.name: id
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: name
properties.definition: Label for the outcome.

properties.name: type
properties.definition: The parameter or characteristic being assessed as one of the values by which the study is assessed.

properties.name: description
properties.definition: Description of the outcome.

properties.name: reference
properties.definition: Structured outcome definition.

properties.name: result
properties.short: Link to results generated during the study
properties.definition: Link to one or more sets of results generated by the study.  Could also link to a research registry holding the results such as ClinicalTrials.gov.

searchParameters.name: category
searchParameters.description: Classifications for the study

searchParameters.name: date
searchParameters.description: When the study began and ended

searchParameters.name: focus
searchParameters.description: Drugs, devices, etc. under study

searchParameters.description: Business Identifier for study

searchParameters.description: Used to search for the study

searchParameters.name: location
searchParameters.description: Geographic region(s) for study

searchParameters.description: Part of larger study
